content.description: In order to study the behavior of oscillating systems, a group of students sets up the three pendulums shown in the figure. Pendulum A consists of a small sphere of mass <math alttext="M sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> connected to a light string of length <math alttext="uppercase L sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. Pendulum B consists of a uniform bar of the same mass <math alttext="M sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and length <math alttext="uppercase L sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> suspended from a pivot at one end. Pendulum C consists of a bar identical to the one in Pendulum B, but the pivot for Pendulum C is in the middle of one of the long edges of the bar. The width of the bars used for pendulums B and C is <math alttext="the fraction uppercase L sub 0 over 15" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mn>15</mn></mfrac></math>, and the rotational inertia about the center of a uniform bar of mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>M</mi></math> and length <math alttext="uppercase L" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>L</mi></math> is <math alttext="I equals, one twelfth M uppercase L squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>I</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>12</mn></mfrac><mi>M</mi><msup><mi>L</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mstyle></math>.
content.question: A new pendulum, Pendulum <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>D</mtext></math>, is constructed like Pendulum <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, except that a bar of length <math alttext="2 uppercase L sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and mass <math alttext="2 M sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> is used. Then pendulums <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> and <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>D</mtext></math> are set to oscillate. When the two pendulums have the same small angular displacement <math alttext="theta sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, how do the magnitudes <math alttext="alpha sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="alpha sub D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mtext>D</mtext></msub></math> of the pendulums’ angular accelerations compare, and what reasoning can be used to support the claim?

choices.label: <math alttext="alpha sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> is greater than <math alttext="alpha sub D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mtext>D</mtext></msub></math>. The ratio of the rotational inertia of <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> to <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>D</mtext></math> is greater than the ratio of the restoring torque of <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> to <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>D</mtext></math> at the same angular displacements.

<math alttext="alpha sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> is greater than <math alttext="alpha sub D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mtext>D</mtext></msub></math>. The ratio of the restoring torque of <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> to <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>D</mtext></math> is greater than the ratio of the rotational inertia of <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> to <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>D</mtext></math> at the same angular displacements.

<math alttext="alpha sub D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mtext>D</mtext></msub></math> is greater than <math alttext="alpha sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math>. The ratio of the rotational inertia of <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> to <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>D</mtext></math> is greater than the ratio of the restoring torque of <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> to <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>D</mtext></math> at the same angular displacements.

<math alttext="alpha sub D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mtext>D</mtext></msub></math> is greater than <math alttext="alpha sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math>. The ratio of the restoring torque of <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> to <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>D</mtext></math> is greater than the ratio of the rotational inertia of <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> to <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>D</mtext></math> at the same angular displacements.

content.answer: <math alttext="alpha sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> is greater than <math alttext="alpha sub D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mtext>D</mtext></msub></math>. The ratio of the rotational inertia of <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> to <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>D</mtext></math> is greater than the ratio of the restoring torque of <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> to <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>D</mtext></math> at the same angular displacements.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
